Literature Review: The legal profession, traditionally characterized by its reliance on human expertise and judgment, is undergoing a significant transformation due to the advent of technology, particularly artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML). This literature review explores the impact of these technological advancements on US and UK law firms, focusing on the integration of AI/ML into legal practices and the resultant changes in the profession. Despite the initial fears that technology would render law firms obsolete, the reality is more nuanced. Technology is reshaping law firms in novel ways, affecting not only back-office operations but also the core tasks of lawyers, creating new career paths, and enabling innovative business models. The adoption of AI/ML in law firms is still in its early stages, with its impact constrained by the current scope of suitable use cases. However, the potential for transformation is significant, as technology begins to affect the very fabric of legal practice. One of the most notable changes is the deployment of technology in the front office, directly impacting lawyers' core tasks of advising clients. AI/ML tools are increasingly being used for legal research, document review, and even predicting case outcomes, thereby enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of legal services (Susskind & Susskind, 2015). This shift not only changes how lawyers work but also raises questions about the future role of human judgment in the legal process. Another transformative aspect of technology in law firms is the creation of alternative career paths for lawyers. As technology automates routine tasks, lawyers are encouraged to develop new skill sets, such as data analysis and technology management, to remain relevant in the profession (Markovic, 2017). This evolution is leading to a more diverse legal workforce, with professionals pursuing careers in legal tech, compliance, and other non-traditional roles. Furthermore, technology is enabling law firms to adopt business models that create value from nonhuman capital and nonlegal human capital. For example, some firms are leveraging AI to offer legal services at scale, reducing reliance on traditional billing models and opening up new revenue streams (Barton & Bibas, 2018). This shift towards technology-driven business models is challenging the traditional structure of law firms and prompting a reevaluation of what it means to practice law. Despite these advancements, the integration of technology into law firms is not without challenges. Issues such as data privacy, ethical considerations, and the need for regulatory frameworks are critical to ensuring that technology enhances rather than undermines the legal profession (McGinnis & Pearce, 2014). Moreover, the success of technology in transforming law firms depends on the concept of organizational complementarity, where technology and human expertise work together to achieve better outcomes (Brynjolfsson & McAfee, 2014). In conclusion, technology is indeed transforming law firms, but not in the way many initially feared. The integration of AI/ML is leading to material changes in the profession, affecting how lawyers work, the career paths available to them, and the business models of law firms. However, the full potential of technology in the legal sector is yet to be realized, and its impact will continue to evolve as new use cases emerge and the profession adapts to these changes.
